Chapter 176: Contemplating Disgust with Food, Part One. All suffering arises from craving food, and it also aids in the arousal of sexual desire.
All suffering in the desire realm arises from food, drink, and sexual desire. In order to cut off craving for food, one should cultivate the contemplation of disgust.
Moreover, it is like the beings at the beginning of the eon, who came down from the heavens and were born by transformation in this world, with bodies having light and freely flying through the air.
When they first ate the earth's essence, those who ate a lot immediately lost their majestic light. In this way, gradually there was old age, sickness, and death.
Up to the present, at the age of a hundred, there are many sufferings and afflictions, all due to craving for food and losing these benefits. Therefore, one should correctly contemplate food.

Moreover, because of attachment to food and drink, sexual desire arises. From sexual desire, other afflictions arise. From other afflictions, one creates unwholesome karma. From unwholesome karma, the three evil destinies increase and the multitudes of gods and humans are harmed. Therefore, all calamities and afflictions are due to craving for food.
Moreover, the characteristics of old age, sickness, and death are all due to food and drink.
Moreover, food is a place of deep craving. Although sexual desire is intense, it cannot afflict people.
Those who eat, whether young or old, lay or ordained, are all afflicted by food.

Moreover, one should eat this food without attachment. For those who have not yet eliminated desire, this is the most difficult. It is like accepting a knife, taking poison, or raising a poisonous snake. Therefore, the Buddha said that one should cultivate the mind and eat with it, not being afflicted by the suffering of craving for food.
There are non-Buddhists who practice fasting. Therefore, the Buddha said:
This food is not to be abandoned. One should think about it and eat it.
If one only abstains from food, but does not eliminate afflictions, then one dies in vain without benefit.
Therefore, the Buddha said:
One should give rise to the thought of disgust towards this food.
Then there is no supreme transgression.
Question:
How should one give rise to the thought of disgust towards food?
Answer:
This food is by nature impure, and even the most delicious food is ultimately impure, therefore one should be disgusted with it.

Moreover, even though clean, fragrant, and delicious food does not immediately benefit the body when it is clean, by chewing with the teeth and being soaked by saliva, it becomes like vomit, falling into the stomach and able to benefit the body. Therefore, one should know it is impure.

Moreover, one does not enjoy food because of knowing it, if a person obtains delicious food, but then vomits it out and cannot eat it again, one should know that it is considered delicious because of the power of ignorance.
Moreover, due to food, one undergoes the suffering of farming, servitude, accumulation, and protection, and because of this, one commits immeasurable offenses.
Moreover, all impurities are caused by food and drink. If there is no food and drink, how can there be skin, bones, blood, flesh, excrement, and other impure substances?

Moreover, all the worms in the evil paths and latrines are born there because of craving for smells and flavors, as explained in the chapter on karma. Sentient beings who die of thirst are born as water insects, those who die in noisy places are born among birds, and those who die with lustful desires are born in wombs, and so on.
Moreover, if one is separated from this food, one attains great bliss, like being born in the form realm or in nirvana.
Moreover, because of food, there is the suffering of farming and so on.
Thus, contemplating food as impure and suffering, one should cultivate the notion of disgust.
Chapter 117: The Contemplation of the Impermanence of All Things in the World The practitioner sees that all things in the world are suffering and the mind has no joy.

Moreover, this practitioner cultivates the concentration of detachment from joy, like the perception of impermanence, the perception of suffering, the perception of non-self, the perception of disgust with food, the perception of death, etc., then the mind does not delight in any worldly thing.
Moreover, this person sees that what is loved increases lust, and seeing what is hated increases anger, therefore both are not delighted in.
Moreover, seeing wealthy and noble people have the suffering of guarding, etc., seeing poor people have the suffering of lack.
Moreover, seeing those in good circumstances are about to fall into bad circumstances, seeing those in bad circumstances are presently suffering various pains.

Moreover, knowing that present wealth and nobility will certainly fall, is also the abode of lust, etc., afflictions. Knowing that present poverty has no conditions by which one can escape, therefore not delighting in any worldly thing.
Moreover, few sentient beings are born in good circumstances, many fall into bad paths, as it is said in the sÅ«tras:
Few are born in good circumstances, many are born in bad circumstances. Seeing this fault, only seek nirvÄá¹‡a.
Moreover, this person sees that greed and other faults always follow sentient beings, like an enemy waiting for an opportunity to kill them. How can one take pleasure in such a thief?
Moreover, one sees that unwholesome karma arises from afflictions and always follows one, and the fruits of unwholesome karma are ultimately inescapable.
As it is said in the sutra:
If you have done evil karma, whether now, in the past, or in the future, you will not be able to escape even if you fly up into the sky.
Therefore, one does not take pleasure [in the world].

Moreover, the eight sufferings such as birth still follow even those with blessings, let alone those without blessings. How can one take pleasure in the world in this way?ğŸ”½Moreover, like a box of poisonous snakes, five robbers with drawn swords, and robbers in an empty village, the sufferings on this shore always follow sentient beings. How can one take pleasure [in the world]?

Moreover, like being swept away by the river of craving for salty and spicy flavors, the sufferings of the five desires, the poisonous thorns of ignorance, and the fire pit always follow sentient beings. How can one take pleasure [in the world]?
Moreover, the practitioner knows that peaceful and blissful happiness is little, while the suffering of decline and distress is much.
Why is this so?

Seeing that in the world, auspicious days and joyous gatherings, flourishing flower forests and abundant fruits, and the peace and happiness of the country cannot last long, those who experience joy are few, while those who suffer are many. Therefore, one does not delight in anything in the world.
Question:
What benefits are gained by cultivating this perception?
Answer:
One's mind does not greedily cling to the various characteristics in the world.
Moreover, by cultivating this perception, one quickly attains liberation and does not dwell long in the cycle of birth and death.
Moreover, this practitioner attains sharp wisdom, always cultivating the characteristics of all faults.
Moreover, this person's mind does not give rise to afflictions, and if they do arise, they quickly cease, like a drop of water falling on hot iron.

Because the practitioner is not fond of the world, he is able to deeply delight in quiescence. If one does not detest the world, then one will not be able to deeply delight in quiescence. Therefore, one should cultivate the notion that all worlds are not enjoyable.
Chapter 178: The Chapter on the Notions of Impurity. Question:
How does one cultivate the notion of impurity?
Answer:
The practitioner sees that the seeds of the body are impure, arising from the impure paths of the parents, a combination of blood and semen.
Moreover, this body is composed of impurities, the juices of rotten and decaying food flowing and soaking it.
Moreover, the place of birth is impure, filled with impurities in the mother's womb.
Moreover, impure things such as feces and urine combine to form the body, constantly flowing with impurities from the nine orifices.
Moreover, wherever the body is placed, that place becomes inauspicious and impure.
Moreover, food, drink, and clothing that come into contact with the human body all become impure and are despised by others.
Moreover, all the substances that make up this body are impure, like bath water or a washbasin.
Moreover, the nails, hair, dirt, grease, mucus, and saliva that come out of the body are all impure.
Moreover, seeing a dead body as impure, what is the difference when this body dies?
One should know that it is originally always impure. At birth, it is only because of the mind of self that it is considered pure.

Moreover, touching a dead person is called impure, and the nails, hair, etc. are always dead objects. Countless dead insects also always touch the body, so one should know that this body is originally impure.
Moreover, impure lice, flies, gnats, and other impure insects always come to touch the body, so one should know that it is impure.
Moreover, this body is like a constantly full impure latrine. Because of this, thousands of insects are born in the latrine, and this body is also like that.
Moreover, this body is like a tomb.
Why is it so?
Because it is a place of corpses, it is called a charnel ground. Many dead insects also dwell within this body.
Moreover, this body can create impurity. Even if it is a clean place with beautiful flowers, clothing, necklaces, etc., because of this body, they all become impure.
Moreover, Brahmins do not accept food from dead households or childbirth households because they are impure.
But in this body, myriad kinds of insects are always born and always die. There is no one from whom one can accept food or drink, so one should know that it is impure.
Moreover, in the world, prisons are considered impure. This body is a prison of myriad kinds of insects, so it is called impure.
Moreover, this body always needs to be bathed. If it were pure, why would it need to be bathed?
Moreover, this body is adorned with beautiful flowers, incense, necklaces, etc. One should know that the nature of this body is impure, and it is adorned with external pure things.

Moreover, this human body is the most impure, as other beings' skin, fur, claws, teeth, tendons, bones, and flesh may have some use, but in the human body, there is nothing to take, because it is the most impure.
Also, like the utpala, padma, and other lotus flowers that grow from impurity, they are therefore called impure.
This body is not like that, as it is not made impure by other things, but is inherently impure.

Moreover, if this body were pure, then it should not be covered with clothes, just as a person covers a heap of excrement with clothes to deceive others. A woman deceives a man in this way by covering her body with ornaments, and a man is also like this. One should know that it is impure.
Moreover, this body constantly emits impurity all over, referring to the nine impure gates and pores, and there is not a single pure one, so one should know that it is impure.
Question:
What benefits are gained by cultivating the thought of impurity?
Answer:

Because one gives rise to lustful desires based on the thought of purity regarding men and women, from this lustful desire the gates to various offenses are opened. Cultivating the thought of impurity can then restrain and subdue lustful desires.
Why is this so?

This body is all foul and impure, but it is only covered by thin skin, so it is not known. It is like covering a heap of impurities with clothes. Those who are fond of cleanliness should stay far away from it.
Moreover, this practitioner destroys all the body with thoughts such as blue and festering, and because the body is destroyed, lustful desires do not arise.
Moreover, one also directly sees colors such as blue and festering.
Question:
If it is not actually blue yet, why is it seen as blue?
Answer:
The practitioner takes this blue characteristic with the power of faith and understanding, and sees all colors as blue and festering.
Question:
How is this contemplation not inverted?
Answer:
This body has a part that is blue and festering.
As it is said in the sutra:
There is a pure nature in wood.
Moreover, by constantly cultivating the characteristics of bluish-black and rotting, one can surpass other colors.

Just as the light of a blue pearl can outshine white, so too, if one cultivates the characteristics of bluish-black and rotting for a long time, then one's impurity will be complete. If one's impurity is complete, then sexual desire will not arise. If sexual desire does not arise, then the doors to all offenses will be closed, and one will follow nirvÄá¹‡a.
Cultivating the perception of impurity brings such benefits.
Chapter 179: The Perception of Death. The practitioner, through the perception of death, is uncertain in his mind about life and lifespan, and therefore should cultivate it.
Moreover, this person always deeply delights in wholesome dharmas and eliminates unwholesome ones.
Why is it so?
Because beings often give rise to unwholesome karma due to forgetting death. If one recollects death, then one can eliminate it.
Moreover, because one always recollects death, one's craving and love for parents, siblings, sisters, relatives, friends, and so forth become thin.
Furthermore, cultivating the perception of death is for one's own benefit, namely being able to single-mindedly gather wholesome dharmas.
Sentient beings in the world often delight in benefiting others, abandoning their own benefits.
Moreover, this person can quickly attain liberation.
Why is it so?
Following the coming and going in the world, there is always this death. This person is disgusted with death and therefore seeks liberation.
Question:
How should one cultivate the thought of death?
Answer:
First, it is said in general that everything is impermanent. Now, one only observes that the body is impermanent. The cessation of the continuity of the aggregates is called death.

Contemplate that this body is impermanent, even more so than external things. It is like a clay pot without the characteristic of solidity. The practitioner observes that the body is even more so than this.
Why is it so?
If this clay pot is protected, it may last for a long time. This body at most does not last a hundred years. Because it lacks solidity, one should contemplate the thought of death.
Moreover, this body is full of harmful dharmas, namely, knives, sticks, sharp blades, enemies, cliffs, undigested food and drink, cold, hot, and wind diseases.
In brief, observing that all sentient beings and all things are harmful to the body, therefore one should cultivate the thought of death.
Moreover, the practitioner sees that the body in every moment is always in a state of decay, not a single moment can be relied upon, therefore he cultivates the thought of death.

Moreover, the practitioner sees that whether one is young or old, healthy or sick, there is no one who can avoid death, he thinks of his own body and will also be like this, therefore he cultivates the thought of death.

Moreover, the practitioner sees that there is karma with uncertain retribution, not all karma is exhausted after a hundred years, because karma is uncertain, death is also uncertain, therefore one should think of death.

Moreover, in the beginningless cycle of birth and death, there is immeasurable karma, there is karma that can obstruct other karma, I also should have karma that causes untimely death, how can I have confidence in this life?

Moreover, the practitioner sees that death has great power and cannot be escaped by soft words, deception, wealth, pursuit, or litigation, just like a huge rock mountain coming from the four directions with no place to flee.
Question:
If a person can delight King Yama, then they can escape death.
Answer:
This is foolish talk.
King Yama has no sovereign power to bring about birth or killing, but can only examine the deeds of good and evil.

If one's retribution is exhausted, they will instead harm their own body and die because of it. Therefore, the practitioner sees that the body has no reliance, no savior, and dwells in the path of death, and thus contemplates the thought of death.

Moreover, the practitioner always sees this body being afflicted by old age and illness, with no stable nature, and cultivates the thought of death because of the continuity of consciousness arising and ceasing in each moment.
Moreover, this practitioner sees that death is certain, while life is uncertain, and cultivates the thought of death because of the uncertainty.
Question:
Why not speak of thoughts of old age, sickness, etc., but only speak of thoughts of death?
Answer:

Old age and sickness can deprive people but cannot make them completely extinct. Sickness deprives one of health, and old age deprives one of youth. Relatives and wealth are still in the remaining body, but death completely takes away.
Moreover, old age, sickness, etc. are the causes and conditions of death, so they are not explained separately.
Moreover, the sutra says:
Death is called the great darkness, without light, without a savior, without companions, and nothing to rely on. It is the most frightening place.
Therefore, one should contemplate death.
Moreover, sentient beings fear the afterlife because of death.
Moreover, there is death in all three realms, but not so for old age and sickness.
Question:
If there is the characteristic of death without being separate from sentient beings, then sentient beings are merely provisional names. Why do practitioners cultivate this thought?
Answer:
Those who do not destroy the characteristics of sentient beings fear death. If one cultivates the thought of death, one will not give rise to fear, and therefore one should cultivate it.

Moreover, the thoughts of impermanence, etc. are called the proximate path, while the thoughts of impurity, disgust, and death, etc. are called the distant path. Those who have not yet attained the path can subdue their minds through these thoughts.

The three thoughts in the latter part of the chapter on the three thoughts, the first one hundred and eighty. The thought of cutting off is as explained in the four right efforts, diligently making energetic progress in order to cut off the evil and unwholesome dharmas that have already arisen.

These evil and unwholesome dharmas are the causes and conditions for the suffering of hell and so forth, and are also the basis for all the suffering of evil reputation, remorse, and so forth. Therefore, they should be cut off.
Question:
How should they be cut off?
Answer:
When one attains the unconditioned, at that time they are cut off.
Moreover, wrong mindfulness is the cause of greed and other afflictions. By cutting off this mindfulness, this dharma is cut off.
Question:
What benefits are obtained by cultivating this thought of cutting off?
Answer:
Those who cultivate this thought always do not follow evil dharmas to be done.
Moreover, this is free from the eight difficulties.
The benefit of the human body is said to be cutting off afflictions.
Moreover, delighting in cutting off afflictions is the benefit of those who wear the Dharma robes, disfigure their bodies, and leave the household life.
If it were not so, then one would be humiliating oneself for no reason.

Moreover, if practitioners delight in cultivating the thought of cutting off, then they would be making offerings to the Buddha with the Dharma, the thought of detachment, and the thought of cessation.
If one wishes to completely extinguish and not give rise to [afflictions], this is called detachment. Remembering this detachment is called the thought of detachment.
Question:
If speaking of the thought of cutting off is precisely the thought of detachment, why speak of it again?
Answer:
One attains detachment from cutting off.
Cutting off refers to eliminating greed and desire, as explained in the sutras:
Because one cuts off greed and desire, the five aggregates are then cut off.
Moreover, the thought of cutting off is the thought of detachment from desire.
Why is this so?
If there is no craving for this dharma, it is called the elimination of this dharma. Therefore, if one attains detachment, suffering and distress cease.
As it is said in the sutra:
One who is detached attains liberation.
Attaining liberation is called elimination. If one enters the remainderless [nirvana], it is called cessation.
Moreover, it is said in the sutra:
There are three natures: the nature of elimination, the nature of detachment, and the nature of cessation.

If the nature of elimination and the nature of detachment are mentioned, it refers to arhats who have eliminated all afflictions and detached from the desires of the three realms, abiding in the nirvana with remainder.
If the nature of cessation is mentioned, it refers to the end of life, abandoning the body, severing the continuity of the aggregates, and entering the remainderless nirvana.
There are also two kinds of liberation: liberation through wisdom and liberation through the mind.
If elimination is mentioned, it refers to the detachment from ignorance, and thus wisdom attains liberation.
If detachment from desires is mentioned, it refers to the detachment from craving, and the mind attains liberation.
The fruits of the two liberations are called cessation.
Moreover, if one speaks of the thought of cutting off, then one speaks of cutting off the defilement of ignorance.
If one speaks of the thought of detachment from desire, then one speaks of cutting off the defilement of desire and the defilement of existence.
If one speaks of the thought of cessation, it is the fruit of these two.
Moreover, as the sutra says:

Because one cuts off all conditioned forces, it is called cutting off; because one detaches from all conditioned forces, it is called detachment; because one extinguishes all conditioned forces, it is called extinction.
Thus, these three meanings are one but have different names.

If one cultivates the thought of impermanence up to the thought of cessation, then all matters are accomplished, one extinguishes afflictions, cuts off the continuity of the aggregates and bonds, and enters nirvÄá¹‡a without remainder.
In the chapter on the requisites for concentration, the first five requisites for concentration Chapter 181: Questions and Answers
You previously explained the truth of the path, namely the requisites for concentration and concentration.
Having explained concentration, you should now explain the requisites for concentration.
Why is this so?
If there are requisites for concentration, then concentration can be accomplished, if not, it cannot be accomplished.
Answer:
The requisites for concentration refer to eleven dharmas:

First, pure observance of precepts; second, obtaining good spiritual friends; third, guarding the sense-gates; fourth, knowing moderation in food and drink; fifth, reducing sleep in the first and last watches of the night; sixth, being endowed with good awakening; seventh, being endowed with good faith and understanding; eighth, being endowed with the factors of practice; ninth, being endowed with the bases of liberation; tenth, being free from obstruction; eleventh, being unattached. Pure observance of precepts means
being free from unwholesome actions, which are called the precepts.

Unwholesome actions refer to killing, stealing, and sexual misconduct, which are the three bodily actions, and false speech, divisive speech, harsh speech, and frivolous speech, which are the four verbal actions. Being free from these offenses is called observing the precepts.
Moreover, practicing good dharmas such as paying respect, welcoming, seeing off, and making offerings is also called precepts.
Because precepts can be the cause for concentration, one should observe them.
Why is it so?
It is just like refining gold, first removing the coarse impurities.
In this way, one first uses precepts to remove the coarse transgressions of breaking precepts, and later uses concentration, etc. to remove the remaining subtle transgressions.
Why is this so?
If there are no precepts, there will be no dhyÄna concentration, because with the condition of precepts, dhyÄna concentration is easily attained.
As it is said in the sÅ«tras:
Precepts are the root of the Way and also the wonderful ladder.
It is also said that precepts are the first vehicle. If one does not board the first vehicle, how can one board the second vehicle, etc.?
It is also said that precepts are the level ground. Standing on this level ground, one can contemplate the four truths.
It is also said that there are two powers: the power of thought and the power of cultivation. The power of thought is precisely upholding precepts, and the power of cultivation is the Way.

First, by contemplating and measuring the faults of breaking precepts and the benefits of upholding precepts, one is able to uphold precepts. Later, after attaining the Way, one naturally avoids evil.
It is also said that precepts are the root of the tree of enlightenment. Without a root, there is no tree, so pure precepts are necessary.

Moreover, the Dharma should be like this: if there is no upholding of precepts, then there is no dhyÄna concentration. It is like the necessary methods of medicine for treating illnesses. In the same way, if there are no precepts for treating the illness of afflictions, then the Dharma medicine is incomplete.
Moreover, it is said that one who purely upholds the precepts has no remorse in the mind, and so forth, up to attaining liberation of the mind free from desires.
All these merits come from upholding the precepts, and therefore they are called the requisites for concentration.

Moreover, there are karmic hindrances and afflictive hindrances. The fruits of these two hindrances are called the hindrance of retribution. If one purely upholds the precepts, then these three hindrances do not exist. If the mind is without hindrances, then one can accomplish concentration.
Moreover, because one who purely upholds the precepts is not destroyed, one will definitely reach nirvÄá¹‡a, like a log in the current of the Ganges.

Moreover, because one purely upholds the precepts, one is able to establish them. Upholding the precepts can restrain unwholesome bodily and verbal actions, and dhyÄna concentration can restrain unwholesome mental actions. In this way, one restrains all afflictions and attains true wisdom, which then completely cuts them off.

Moreover, the tower of the path is made of precepts as pillars, the city of the mind of meditation is surrounded by precepts as ramparts, crossing the river of birth and death uses precepts as bridges, entering the assembly of good people uses precepts as seals, and the eight straight holy fields are bounded by precepts.
Just as a field without boundaries cannot hold water, so too if there are no pure precepts, the water of concentration cannot remain.
Question:
What is called pure observance of precepts?
Answer:
If the practitioner deeply does not enjoy doing evil, not fearing the afterlife or bad reputation, it is called pure observance of precepts.
Moreover, because the practitioner's mind is pure, the precepts are pure. As the Sutra on the Seven Kinds of Sexual Desire says:
Although the body does not commit offenses, because the mind is impure, the precepts are also impure.
Moreover, the causes and conditions for breaking precepts are the various afflictions. If one can restrain them, it is pure observance of precepts.

Moreover, the precepts upheld by the hearers are only for nirvana. Those who seek the Buddha Way, with a mind of great compassion for all sentient beings, do not grasp at the characteristics of the precepts, enabling these precepts to be like the nature of enlightenment. Upholding the precepts in this way is called pure.

As for good and virtuous friends, the sutra says that one can give rise to right views through two causes and conditions: first, hearing the Dharma from others; second, correctly recollecting it oneself.
Those from whom one hears the Dharma are called good and virtuous friends.
Question:
If that is so, then why is it only said to be good and virtuous friends?
Answer:
The sutra says that Ananda asked the Buddha:
When I was sitting in meditation in one place, I had this thought:
Encountering good and virtuous friends is half the cause and condition for attaining the Way.
The Buddha said:
Do not speak in this way.
Good and virtuous friends are the complete cause and condition for attaining the Way.
Why is this so?
Sentient beings who are born, grow old, get sick, and die, if they have me as a good and virtuous friend, then they will all attain liberation from birth, old age, sickness, and death.
Moreover, sentient beings, due to good and virtuous friends, are able to increase the five dharmas such as precepts, just as the sÄla tree increases five things due to the Himalayas.
Moreover, the Buddha himself delights in good and virtuous friends. For example, when he first attained enlightenment, he thought like this:
If a person has no teacher, then he has no fear and no respectful mind. He is always covered by evil dharmas and has no peaceful conduct.
Whom should I take as my teacher? Whom should I rely on to abide?
Having had this thought, he looked all around and saw that there was no one superior to himself. He then thought to himself:
The Dharma I have attained leads to becoming a Buddha. I should still rely on this Dharma.
Brahma and other gods also praised him, saying:
So it is, there is no Buddha who surpasses the Dharma. All Buddhas take the Dharma as their teacher.

Moreover, good and virtuous friends are like bright lamps. Those with eyes but no lamps cannot see. In the same way, although practitioners have the causes and conditions of blessings and sharp faculties, without good and virtuous friends, they will not benefit.
Question:
Who are good and virtuous friends?
The answer is:
Those who can cause people to increase wholesome dharmas are called good and virtuous friends.
Moreover, all good and virtuous people who abide in the true Dharma are good and virtuous friends in the heavens and among humans.
Guarding the sense-doors refers to right mindfulness.
Practitioners cannot close their eyes and not look, but should be single-mindedly mindful of what is present.

It is also called right wisdom, because with this right wisdom one can destroy the objects of the senses. Because one can destroy the objects of the senses, one does not grasp at characteristics. Because one does not grasp at characteristics, one does not follow false names.
If one does not guard the senses, because one grasps at characteristics, afflictions arise and flow through the five senses, destroying wholesome dharmas such as precepts.
If one is able to guard the sense-doors, then precepts and so forth become firm.
Knowing moderation in food means not eating for the sake of physical strength, sexual desire, or greedy taste, but for the sake of sustaining the body.
The question is:
Why do practitioners sustain the body?
The answer is:
In order to cultivate wholesome dharmas, if one is apart from wholesome dharmas, then there is no path, and without the path, there is no liberation from suffering.

If a person does not eat for the sake of cultivating wholesome dharmas, then they are pointlessly nourishing enemies and destroying the merit of the patron, harming the offerings of others. One should not eat the food of others in this way.
Question:
What is the measure of food and drink?
Answer:
That which can sustain the body is called the measure.
Question:
What kind of food should one eat?
Answer:
If food does not increase physical illnesses such as cold and heat, or mental illnesses such as greed and anger, then it should be eaten.
This food should also be eaten in a timely manner. If one knows that this food can increase illnesses such as cold, heat, greed, and anger at this time, then it should not be eaten.
Question:

The non-Buddhists say that if one eats pure food, then one can obtain pure blessings, referring to food that is pleasing to the mind in color, aroma, taste, and touch, which is sprinkled with water and blessed before eating. This is called pure.
What is the meaning of this?
Answer:
There is no definite purity in food and drink.
Why is this?

If leftover food is considered impure, then all food and drink are not without leftovers. For example, milk is leftover from calves, honey is leftover from bees, water is leftover from insects, flowers are leftover from bees, and fruits are leftover from birds.
Moreover, this body is born from impurity and its nature is impure, filled with impurity.
Food and drink are originally impure, and after entering the body, there is nothing pure about them. It is only due to inverted delusion that one falsely considers them to be pure.
Question:
If there is absolutely no purity, then what is the difference from a chandala?
Answer:

Moreover, one obtains food through proper means such as not killing, not stealing, and not engaging in wrong livelihood. One contemplates the faults of food and sprinkles it with the water of wisdom before eating. It is not that simply sprinkling it with water is considered to be making it pure.
As for reducing sleep in the first and last watches of the night, the practitioner knows that accomplishments come from diligence, so they do not sleep.
Moreover, they see that sleep is empty and has nothing to gain.
If you take sleep as pleasure, this pleasure is little and not worth mentioning.
Moreover, practitioners do not enjoy dwelling with afflictions, just as people do not enjoy living with enemies and thieves. How could there be people who would sleep in the midst of thieves?
Therefore, they do not sleep.
Question:
If sleep comes forcefully, how can it be dispelled?
Answer:
This person attains the taste of the Buddha's teachings and deeply rejoices in his mind, thus he can dispel it.
Moreover, he contemplates the faults of old age, sickness, and death in the cycle of birth and death, and his mind becomes fearful, thus he does not sleep.

Moreover, the practitioner sees that attaining a human body with complete faculties, encountering the Buddha's teachings, and being able to distinguish good and bad is extremely difficult. Now, if he does not seek liberation, when will he attain liberation?
Therefore, he diligently applies effort to dispel sleep.

Chapter 182: Evil Thoughts Chapter 182: Evil Thoughts, 182. Those who are endowed with good thoughts, even if they do not sleep, give rise to unwholesome thoughts, namely, thoughts of desire, anger, and harm, thoughts of relatives, thoughts of homeland, thoughts of immortality, thoughts of benefiting others, thoughts of despising others, and so forth. It is better to sleep than to give rise to these unwholesome thoughts.

One should correctly contemplate the good thoughts of leaving and so forth, namely, the thoughts of leaving, the thoughts of non-anger and non-harm, and the thoughts of the eight kinds of great people.
Thoughts of desire refer to thoughts that arise based on desire, seeing benefits and pleasures in the five desires, which are called thoughts of desire.
Causing harm and distress to sentient beings, this is called thoughts of anger and thoughts of harm.
Practitioners should not contemplate these three kinds of thoughts.
Why is it so?
Contemplating these three kinds of thoughts will result in grave offenses.
Moreover, the faults of greed and so forth have already been explained before. Because of these faults, one should not contemplate them.
Question:
Why are delusion, etc., not mentioned as mental activities?
The answer is:
These three evil mental activities arise in sequence, while other afflictions do not do so.

When a practitioner sometimes thinks of the five desires, greed arises. Because he does not obtain what he desires, he becomes angry. Anger becomes vexation. Therefore, delusion, etc., are not mentioned.
Moreover, the result produced by delusion is precisely greed and anger. If unwholesome karma arises from greed and anger, these three mental activities are called the causes of unwholesome karma.
As a sutra says:
It is like a piece of land, where smoke comes out at night and fire burns during the day. The smoke is the mental activity, and the fire is called karma.
The mental activity of relatives means giving rise to various thoughts because of relatives.
Wishing for relatives to obtain peace and happiness, if one thinks of their decline and distress, then sorrow arises.
If one thinks of various activities shared with relatives, this is called the mental activity of relatives.
A practitioner should not recall this mental activity.
Why is this?
When one first goes forth, one has already abandoned relatives. Now relying on this realization is not appropriate.
Moreover, if an ordained person still thinks of relatives, then the renunciation of family members is in vain and nothing is accomplished.

Because of affection for relatives, greed arises. Because of greed, one protects and guards. The causes and conditions of protection and guarding give rise to the karma of whips and sticks, and so on, in sequence. Therefore, one should not give rise to thoughts of relatives.
Moreover, uniting with relatives cannot increase wholesome dharmas.
Moreover, the practitioner should think that all sentient beings transmigrate in birth and death, and there are none who are not relatives. Why be biased in attachment?
Moreover, because of relatives in birth and death, there is worry, sorrow, crying, and tears forming the great ocean. Now, if one is greedy and attached again, suffering will be endless.
Moreover, sentient beings are mutually intimate because of the causes and conditions of benefit, but there is no certainty.

Moreover, thinking of relatives is a characteristic of foolishness. Foolish people in the world, without benefiting themselves, want to benefit others. If one thinks of relatives, then self-benefit is diminished.
For these reasons, practitioners should not give rise to thoughts of relatives.
As for thoughts of one's homeland, the practitioner may think:
In such-and-such a place, the country is prosperous, peaceful, and secure. If I go there, I can find happiness.
Moreover, the mind is restless, wanting to travel around and observe everywhere.
Practitioners should not give rise to such thoughts.
Why is this?

All countries have faults and shortcomings. Some countries are very cold, some are very hot, some are very dangerous, some have many illnesses, some have many thieves. There are various such faults, so one should not think of them.
Moreover, those who are restless will lose their meditative concentration.
A place that can increase goodness and virtue is considered good. What need is there to observe all countries?
All countries can only be heard of from afar. When one arrives, they may not live up to expectations, because worldly people often speak in excess.
Those who travel to various countries will experience various sufferings.
Moreover, the body is the cause of suffering. Carrying this cause of suffering wherever one goes, one will experience various sufferings.
Moreover, the experience of suffering and pleasure is all due to karmic causes. Even if one goes far away, there is no benefit.
Therefore, one should not give rise to the notion of a country.
The notion of immortality means the practitioner thinks like this:

I will slowly cultivate the path later. First, I should recite the sutras, vinaya, abhidharma, miscellaneous scriptures, and bodhisattva canon. I will extensively study the non-Buddhist classics and accumulate many disciples. I will lead good people to make offerings to the four stupas, and inspire sentient beings to greatly give in charity. Later, I will cultivate the path. This is called the notion of immortality.
The practitioner should not give rise to such thoughts.
Why is it so?

The time of death is uncertain and cannot be known in advance. If one is engaged in other affairs and then one's life ends, one will not be able to cultivate the path. Later, when one is about to die, one will regret and worry:
I have foolishly raised this body in vain without attaining anything, dying like an animal.
As it is said in the sutras:
Ordinary people should subdue their minds in twenty ways, thinking like this:
I am only different in appearance and clothing from worldly people, empty and without attainment, up to I will be undisciplined until death.
And the wise do not do what should not be done.
As it is said in the Dharma Verses:
Do not do what should not be done, always do what should be done, with a mind of mindfulness and wisdom, the defilements will then be exhausted.
And it is said in the sutras:
Those who have not attained the Four Truths, expediently wish to attain them, should exert diligence even more than saving their head from catching fire.
Therefore, one should not give rise to the notion of immortality.

Moreover, the notion of immortality is the breath of foolishness. How could a wise person, knowing that life is impermanent like dew on a blade of grass, be able to guarantee even a single thought?ğŸ”½And it is said in the sutras:
The Buddha asked the bhikshus:
How do you cultivate the thought of death?
Some replied to the Buddha:
I cannot guarantee even seven years.
Some say six years, and so on, decreasing to a moment.
The Buddha said:
You all are practicing the contemplation of death carelessly.
A bhiká¹£u bared his right shoulder and said to the Buddha:
I do not guarantee returning to inhalation after exhalation, nor do I guarantee returning to exhalation after inhalation.
The Buddha said:
Excellent, excellent!
You truly practice the contemplation of death.
Therefore, one should not give rise to the notion of immortality.
As for the notion of benefiting others, if one wishes to bring benefit to those who are not relatives and thinks:
May such-and-such be wealthy, noble, at ease, and able to practice generosity, while such-and-such is not so,
a practitioner should not give rise to such a notion.
Why is it so?
It is not by thinking that one can cause others to experience suffering or happiness, but only by oneself destroying and disturbing the concentrated mind.
The question is asked:
Is wishing to bring benefit to others not the compassionate mind?
The answer is:
A practitioner seeking the Way should contemplate the foremost and true benefit, namely impermanence and so forth.
Although there may be a little merit in this, it can hinder the path, with little benefit and much harm, because it disturbs the concentrated mind.
If one thinks of benefiting others with a scattered mind, one will not be able to see the faults of greed and attachment, so one should not think of it.
As for the notion of despising others, the practitioner should not think:
This person's family lineage, appearance, wealth and status, skills and abilities, precepts, sharp faculties, dhyÄna concentration, wisdom, etc. are all inferior to mine.
The practitioner should not give rise to such notions.
Why is this?
Because all things are impermanent, what difference is there between superior, middling, and inferior?
Moreover, this person's body, hair, nails, teeth, etc. are all called impure, and there is no difference between them.
Moreover, old age, sickness, death, etc. are also the same in terms of decay and distress.
Moreover, the inner and outer sufferings and afflictions of all sentient beings are the same without difference.
Moreover, the wealth and status of ordinary people are the causes and conditions of their offenses, and moreover, wealth and status do not last and will return to poverty and lowliness.
Therefore, one should not give rise to the notion of despising others.
Moreover, this pride is a part of ignorance. How can the wise give rise to such a perception?
Chapter 183: Good Perception The one who emerges from perception delights in detachment.
If one is detached from the five desires and the form and formless realms, delighting in this detachment is called emerging from perception.
This joy of detachment is free from suffering. Following attachment brings suffering, while being free from attachment brings joy.
Among the perceptions, two perceptions are called joy, namely the perception of non-hatred and the perception of non-affliction.
Why is this so?
These two perceptions are called perceptions of peace and security, as explained in the chapter on the TathÄgata.
The TathÄgata always has two perceptions present, namely the perception of peace and security and the perception of detachment.
The perception of peace and security is precisely the perception of non-hatred and non-affliction.
The perception of detachment is precisely the perception of emergence.
Moreover, recollecting these three perceptions increases blessings and virtues, and also enables the mind to attain concentration and purity.
Moreover, it is contemplated that these three kinds of awareness can obstruct the fetters, and because the fetters are severed, one can quickly realize their cessation.
Moreover, the practitioner, by delighting in seclusion and accumulating wholesome dharmas, is thus able to quickly attain liberation.

The eight kinds of great awareness of the adults, in the Buddha's teachings, those who have few desires are able to obtain benefits, not those with many desires. Those who are content, those who are secluded, those who are diligent, those who have right mindfulness, those whose minds are in concentration, those who have wisdom, and those who are free from conceptual proliferation are able to obtain benefits, not those who engage in conceptual proliferation. These are called the eight.

As for the practitioner with few desires, in order to cultivate the path, one necessarily desires what is necessary, but does not seek many other unnecessary things. This is called having few desires.

As for being content, some people, whether due to circumstances, for the sake of upholding the precepts, or in order to cause others to attain purity of mind, therefore take little but do not consider it sufficient;
if a person takes little and considers it sufficient, this is called being content.
Some people, although they take few things, seek good ones. This is called few desires, not contentment.
If one obtains few things, this is called contentment.
Question:
If taking what is necessary is called few desires, all sentient beings are called few desires, because each has what is necessary.
Answer:
The practitioner takes with an unattached mind just for use, so he does not take too much, unlike worldly people who take many things for adornment, fame, and reputation.
Question:
Why do practitioners have few desires and contentment?
Answer:
In guarding and so forth, they see the faults.
Moreover, hoarding useless things is a sign of foolishness.
Moreover, renunciant people should not accumulate like laypeople.
Because of these faults, they have few desires and contentment.

Moreover, if practitioners do not have few desires and contentment, then greedy thoughts gradually increase. For the sake of wealth and profit, they seek what should not be sought. Because of deeply attaching to wealth and profit, there will never be peace and security.
Moreover, this person left home for the joy of seclusion, but because of greed for profit, they forget their original purpose.
Moreover, they are also unable to abandon all afflictions.
Why is this?
If one cannot even abandon external things, how much less so internal phenomena?
Moreover, seeing that material gain is the cause of decline and distress, like hail damaging crops, one should always cultivate few desires and contentment.
Moreover, seeing that donated goods are difficult to repay, like a debt that is not repaid, one will later experience suffering and distress.
Moreover, seeing that material gain is abandoned by all Buddhas and other good people, as the Buddha said:
I do not associate with material gain, let material gain not associate with me.
Moreover, this practitioner is replete with good dharmas, so they abandon material gain, as the Buddha said:
The gods are still unable to attain the true wisdom bliss of leaving behind happiness, detachment, and tranquility, as I have attained.
Therefore, I abandon offerings and praise.
Moreover, as ÅšÄriputra said:
I skillfully cultivate the formless absorption of emptiness, and when observing all external myriad things, I regard them as snot and spittle.
Moreover, the practitioner does not see anyone who is content with receiving desires, just like drinking salty water cannot quench thirst. Therefore, one diligently seeks wisdom to be content.
Moreover, one sees that those with much desire always make vows, seeking much but obtaining little, so they always have suffering.
Moreover, one sees that beggars are despised by people and not respected as much as those with few desires.
Moreover, it is inappropriate for renunciants to seek much. It is appropriate to not accept what is given, therefore one should practice few desires and contentment.
As for seclusion, if one practices physical seclusion among lay and ordained people, and practices mental seclusion from afflictions, this is called seclusion.
Question:
Why does the practitioner avoid?
Answer:
Although those who have left the household life have not yet attained the Way, they take distance as joy;
Those in white robes and so forth are in the midst of the confusion of women's colors and will never have peace and joy.
Moreover, if one is distant, the mind is easily extinguished, just as water that is not disturbed naturally becomes clear, so one practices distance.
Moreover, this Dharma of distance is praised by the Buddhas as numerous as the sands of the Ganges River.
How do we know this?
The Buddha saw that the bhiká¹£us were sitting in meditation near the village, and his mind was not pleased.
Moreover, he saw the bhiká¹£us sleeping in an empty place, and the Buddha was delighted in his mind.
Why is this?

Sitting in meditation near a village has many conditions that cause the concentrated mind to be scattered, causing one to fail to attain what should be attained and fail to realize what should be realized;
Although sleeping in an empty place is a little lazy, if one arises and seeks concentration, then the scattered mind can be collected, and the collected mind can attain liberation.

Moreover, because of grasping characteristics, greed and other afflictions arise. In the formless realm, the characteristics of space and so forth make it easy to eliminate afflictions, just as fire naturally extinguishes when there is no fuel.
Moreover, the sÅ«tras say:

If a bhiká¹£u delights in dwelling in the assembly, delights in mixed speech, and does not leave the assembly, he will not even be able to attain liberation through love, let alone attain indestructible liberation;
One who practices far-removed [from the assembly] will certainly be able to realize both [liberation through love and indestructible liberation].

It is just as a lamp, when separated from the wind, is able to illuminate clearly. The practitioner is like this. Because of practicing far-removed [from the assembly], he is able to attain true wisdom.
Vigor: If the practitioner practices right effort, cutting off unwholesome dharmas and cultivating wholesome dharmas, diligently practicing in this is called vigor.
In this way, he will be able to obtain the benefits of the Buddha's teachings.
Why is this so?
Because by accumulating wholesome dharmas, they increase day by day, just as the utpala and padma flowers increase with the water [they are grown in];
A lazy practitioner is like a wooden pestle, diminishing day by day from the time it is first made.
Moreover, those who are diligent are always joyful in their minds because they attain benefits.
Those who are indolent and negligent are always troubled because evil dharmas cover their minds.
Moreover, for those who are diligent, wholesome dharmas always increase and are never diminished, moment by moment.
Moreover, those who deeply practice diligence attain the supreme state, namely the path of the Buddhas.
As it is said in the sÅ«tras, the Buddha told Ä€nanda:
By deeply cultivating diligence, one can reach the path of the Buddhas.
Moreover, those who are diligent easily attain a concentrated mind.
Moreover, even those with dull faculties who are diligent quickly attain liberation from birth and death, while those with sharp faculties who are indolent are unable to attain it.
Moreover, all the benefits in this world and the next world, whether worldly or supramundane, are all due to diligence, while all the troubles and calamities in the world are all due to indolence.
Seeing in this way the faults of indolence and the benefits of diligence, one should be mindful of diligence.
Right mindfulness means always cultivating right wisdom with regard to the body, feelings, mind, and dharmas.
Question:
What benefits are attained by being mindful of these four dharmas?
Answer:
Evil and unwholesome dharmas do not come to enter the mind, just as when guarded well, evil people cannot enter.
Also, it is like a full jar that no longer receives water. This person is like this, with wholesome dharmas filling up, not allowing any evil.

Also, if one cultivates this right mindfulness, then it includes all wholesome dharmas that lead to liberation, just as when drinking seawater, one drinks all the rivers, because all waters are in the great ocean.
Also, cultivating this right mindfulness is called abiding in the place of mastery, which cannot be destroyed by the demons and evil people of afflictions, like the analogy of the hawk and partridge.
Also, this person's mind abides peacefully and is difficult to move, like a round jar entering a container.
Also, this person will soon attain benefits, as explained in the Bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä« SÅ«tra: The bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä«s asked Ä€nanda:
Venerable One!
We have well cultivated mindfulness and have realized differences from before.
Ä€nanda said:
Good!
This Dharma should be so.
The mind of concentration, if one cultivates the mind of concentration and attains subtle benefits, as explained in the sutras:
One who cultivates the mind of concentration can know things as they really are.
Moreover, this person attains superhuman dharmas, namely emitting water and fire from the body, freely flying through the air, and so forth.
Moreover, this person attains bliss, which even the gods and Brahma kings cannot match.
Moreover, this person is called one who should do what should be done, and does not do what should not be done.
Moreover, if one skillfully cultivates concentration, then good dharmas always increase.

Moreover, one who cultivates concentration does not regret in the later mind. This person is called one who attains the fruit of going forth, and is also called one who follows the Buddha's teachings.
Unlike other people who vainly receive offerings, this person can repay the blessings of giving, while others cannot.
Moreover, this concentrated mind is cherished by all Buddhas and sages, and is also able to bear all good dharmas.
Moreover, if one can definitely accomplish it, one attains the noble path; if one cannot accomplish it, one is reborn in the pure heavens, namely the form and formless realms.
Why is this?
Because giving and so forth cannot obtain such things as being able to ultimately not create various evils.
As it is said in the sÅ«tras:
If a child from birth practices loving-kindness, can he give rise to evil thoughts and contemplate evil things?
No, it is not so.
World-Honored One!
This is all the power of concentration.
Moreover, the concentrated mind is called the true cause of wisdom. True wisdom can exhaust all conditioned activities. Because conditioned activities are exhausted, all suffering and distress cease.

Moreover, the practitioner should be able to accomplish all worldly and supramundane matters by simply recollecting them without exerting additional effort. Other people are not even able to give rise to the thought of measuring what they can obtain. Therefore, it is said that the concentrated mind can obtain benefits.
As for wisdom, in the mind of the wise, afflictions do not arise. If they do arise, they immediately cease, like a drop of water falling on an iron.
Moreover, the mind of the wise does not give rise to various thoughts, and if they do arise, they are extinguished, like dew on grass that disappears when the sun rises.
Moreover, if one has the eye of wisdom, one can observe the Buddha Dharma, just as one with eyes can make use of the sun.
Moreover, the wise are said to have obtained their share of the Buddha Dharma, like a born child who obtains their share of their father's wealth.
Moreover, the wise are said to have life, while others are said to be dead.
Moreover, the wise are called true practitioners of the Way, because they can know the Way.
Moreover, the wise know the taste of the Buddha Dharma, like the tongue faculty that can distinguish the five tastes.
Moreover, the wise are unshakable in their minds regarding the Buddha Dharma, like a mountain of stone that cannot be moved by the wind.
Moreover, the wise are called faith, because they have attained the four kinds of faith and do not follow others.
Moreover, those who have attained the holy wisdom faculty are called disciples of the Buddha, while others are called ordinary worldlings.
Therefore, it is said that the wise can obtain benefit.
As for being free from frivolous discourse, discussing in terms of sameness or difference is called frivolous discourse.
As Ananda asked Shariputra:
If the six sense bases are completely extinguished upon the cessation of desire, is there anything else?
Shariputra said:
If there is anything else left after the complete extinction of the six sense bases upon the cessation of desire, it is indescribable, yet you ask about it.
If it is non-existent, both existent and non-existent, or neither existent nor non-existent, the question and answer are the same.
Question:
Why is this indescribable?
Answer:
This question is about whether the self and dharmas are the same or different. Therefore, it is not answered.

I have no fixed position, but only provisionally use the name in the five aggregates. If I answer with existence or non-existence, etc., I would fall into eternalism or nihilism. If I explain the self through causes and conditions, it is not idle speculation.

Moreover, if one sees the emptiness of sentient beings and the emptiness of dharmas, there is no idle speculation. Therefore, it is said that one who is free from idle speculation obtains the benefit of the Buddha's teachings.
This is called complete good understanding.

184. Chapter on the Five Prerequisites for the Later Five Concentrations, Part 184. Those who possess good faith and understanding, if practitioners can delight in nirvana and detest samsara, it is called good faith and understanding. Such faith and understanding can quickly attain liberation.
Moreover, those who delight in nirvana have no attachments in their minds, and those who delight in nirvana have no fear.
Why is this so?
If the mind of an ordinary person thinks of nirvana, they will immediately become frightened:
I will be forever lost.
Question:
For what reasons do they have faith and understanding in nirvana?
Answer:
Practitioners who see the impermanence, suffering, emptiness, and non-self of the world will then give rise to the thought of quiescent extinction in nirvana.
Moreover, this person's fundamental nature and afflictions are light, and upon hearing the explanation of nirvana, their mind will delight in faith.

Moreover, if one follows a good teacher or reads scriptures and hears about the faults of birth and death, as explained in scriptures such as the Beginningless Sutra and the Five Messengers Sutra, one will become disgusted with birth and death and have faith in nirvana.
As for the factors of practice, as explained in the sutras, there are five factors:
1. Having faith, 2. A mind free from flattery, 3. Few illnesses, 4. Diligence, 5. Wisdom.
Having faith means having no doubts or regrets in one's mind regarding the Three Jewels and the Four Truths. Because one has no doubts or regrets, one can quickly attain concentration.
Moreover, one who has faith has a mind full of joy, and thus can quickly attain concentration.
Moreover, one who has faith has a well-regulated mind and is easily focused, and thus quickly attains concentration.
Question:
If wisdom arises from concentration and can later eliminate doubts, why is it said that one is free from doubts after attaining concentration?
Answer:
One can eliminate doubts through much learning, not through attaining concentration.

Moreover, being born in a family with deep faith, associating with those who have faith, always cultivating faith, although not yet attaining concentration, yet being able to be free from doubt, and so on.
As for being without deceit, with an honest mind and nothing to hide, then it is easy to be liberated, just as a person who tells the doctor the details of their illness is easy to cure.
As for having few illnesses, one is able to make progress in the early and late parts of the night without stopping. If one has many illnesses, then it interferes with practicing the Way.
As for being diligent, in order to seek the Way, one always diligently practices, just as when drilling for fire, if one does not stop, then one quickly obtains fire.
As for being wise, because one has wisdom, one attains the fruits of the four things, namely the noble path.
Question:
The dharmas such as the foundations of mindfulness are also called the factors of the practitioner. Why only speak of these five dharmas?
Answer:
Although they are all factors, these dharmas are the most excellent, and are what the practitioner needs, and therefore they are spoken of alone.
Also, being free from all evil and gathering all good is called the part of practice, as explained in the Sutra of Gautama.
Being endowed with the bases of liberation refers to the five bases of liberation.

First, if the Buddha or a superior bhiká¹£u preaches the Dharma for him, according to what he hears he is able to penetrate the meaning of the words, and because of his penetration his mind gives rise to joy, with joy the body becomes tranquil, with bodily tranquility one experiences bliss, with blissful experience the mind becomes concentrated, this is the first basis of liberation.

Because the practitioner abides in this basis of liberation, his mindfulness becomes firm and his mind becomes concentrated, all his defilements are extinguished, and he will certainly attain nirvÄá¹‡a.

Second, reciting the sÅ«tras well; third, preaching the Dharma for others; fourth, contemplating the various dharmas in solitude; fifth, well grasping the characteristics of concentration, namely the nine characteristics and so forth, all as explained above.
Question:
Why do the Buddha and superior bhiká¹£us
preach the Dharma for this practitioner?
Answer:
Because one who is able to receive the Dharma can attain great benefits, therefore it is taught for them.

Moreover, this bhiká¹£u left home due to the Buddha, and his faculties are pure and mature, therefore the Dharma is taught for him. The venerable bhiká¹£u is taught the Dharma because of the same occupation.
Moreover, this practitioner must hear the Dharma, therefore it is taught for him.
Moreover, this person has the mature merits of pure precepts and so forth, just like a complete vessel that is able to receive and hold, therefore the Dharma is taught for him.

This is called the three kinds of wisdom. Understanding language is the wisdom of much learning, understanding the meaning is the wisdom of reflection, and from these two kinds of wisdom one is able to give rise to mental joy, up to the arising of suchness wisdom through the concentration of the mind, this is called the wisdom of cultivation.
These three kinds of wisdom have three kinds of fruits, namely disgust, detachment, and liberation.

Moreover, hearing the Dharma, reciting it, and expounding it for others is the wisdom of much learning, contemplating the various dharmas is called the wisdom of reflection, and skillfully grasping the characteristics of concentration is called the wisdom of cultivation.
Question:
What is the difference between the liberation of the mind and the destruction of the contaminants?
The answer:
It is said that the liberation of the mind is due to concentration blocking afflictions, and the destruction of the contaminants is due to permanently severing afflictions.
The question:

If precepts and other dharmas are also places of liberation, as it is said that by upholding precepts the mind does not regret, and by the mind not regretting there is joy, etc., or liberation is also attained through giving, etc., why are only these five dharmas mentioned?
The answer:
They are said to be unique because they are superior.
Another question:
What is superior about these dharmas?
The answer:
They are the proximate causes of liberation, while precepts, etc., are distant and therefore not mentioned.
Another question:
How do we know they are proximate causes?
The answer:

When practitioners hear the Dharma, they know that the aggregates, sense bases, and sense fields, etc., are merely a combination of dharmas without a self, and therefore they break through the provisional names. Breaking through the provisional names is precisely liberation, and therefore they are called proximate causes.
Moreover, a sutra says:
The merit of much learning means not following the teachings of others, easily concentrating the mind, and so on.
For this reason, it is known to be a proximate cause.
Moreover, the Buddha's teachings have great merit, able to extinguish afflictions and reach nirvana, etc.
In this quiescent and extinguished Dharma, if one listens, recites, or contemplates by oneself, one will quickly attain liberation. Therefore, it is called a proximate cause.

Moreover, giving leads to great wealth, upholding precepts leads to nobility, and much learning leads to wisdom. Because of wisdom, one can exhaust all defilements, not because of wealth and nobility. Therefore, it is known to be a proximate cause.
Moreover, ÅšÄriputra and others are called great sages, all due to much learning.
Question:
If the mind is easily concentrated due to much learning, why did Ä€nanda not attain liberation in the first, middle, or last watches of the night?
Answer:
Ä€nanda attained liberation as soon as his head touched the pillow. Therefore, he is often included in the category of rare and extraordinary people. Why was he not quick?
Moreover, Ä€nanda's diligence in this night was slightly excessive, and because of his exhaustion, he was unable to attain liberation.
Moreover, Ä€nanda made a vow:
Tonight I will surely attain the exhaustion of defilements.
It is also like the Bodhisattva's vow at the site of enlightenment. Who has this power?
One like Ä€nanda all has the power of much learning.
As for being unobstructed, it refers to the three obstructions: the obstruction of karma, the obstruction of retribution, and the obstruction of afflictions.
If a person is without these three obstructions, they will not fall into difficult circumstances. If they are free from difficulties, then they are able to receive the Way.
Moreover, this person is said to be endowed with four wheels, namely: a good country, relying on good people, oneself giving rise to right vows, and the blessings of past lives.

Moreover, one is able to accomplish the four factors of a stream-enterer, namely: being close to good people, delighting in listening to the right Dharma, oneself correctly recollecting, and being able to practice in accordance with the Dharma.
Moreover, one is able to abandon the three dharmas such as greed, as explained in the sutra:
If one does not cut off the three, then one will not be able to cross over old age, sickness, and death.

Not attached means not attached to this shore, not attached to the other shore, not sinking in the middle stream, not emerging on land, not being taken by humans or non-humans, not entering whirlpools, and not rotting by itself.
This shore refers to the six internal sense bases.
The other shore refers to the six external sense bases.
The middle stream refers to craving and joy.
Land refers to conceit.
Being taken by humans refers to associating with laypeople and renunciants.
Being taken by non-humans refers to observing precepts in order to be reborn in the heavens.
Whirlpools refer to turning away from the precepts.
Rotting refers to breaking the grave prohibitions.

If a person conceives of self in the internal sense bases, they will give rise to a sense of mine in the external sense bases. Because craving and joy arise from the internal and external sense bases, they will then sink in the middle. From this, conceit arises.
Why is this?
If a person is attached to the body and experiences pleasure, when others come to belittle them, they will give rise to conceit.
In this way, the greed and joy of self and self-possession, and the arrogance of self, disturb the mind, and therefore one is able to accomplish other things.
Question:
In this analogy, what is taken to be the water?

If the eightfold noble path is taken to be the water, then the inner and outer six sense bases should not be taken to be the shore, nor should greed, joy, etc. be taken to be the middle stream, nor should there be whirlpools and decay.
If craving is taken to be the water, how can one follow it to reach nirvana?
Answer:
The eightfold noble path is taken to be the water. An analogy does not necessarily have to be complete. In this way, if a log avoids the eight difficulties, it will surely reach the great ocean.

In the same way, a bhiká¹£u who avoids the various difficulties of the streams will follow the flow of the water of the eightfold noble path and enter nirvana.ğŸ”½It is said that milk is like a conch, only taking its color and not its hardness or softness;
It is said that the face is like the moon, only taking its fullness and not its shape.

Moreover, when the practitioner emerges from the holy path and becomes attached to internal and external sense objects, it is not like this wood that becomes attached to this shore, the other shore, or rots in the water.
Some masters say that just as the water of the Ganges River must reach the great ocean, so must the eightfold noble path reach nirvana, and therefore it is used as a metaphor.
Thus, the ten factors necessary for concentration are explained in brief. If one possesses these factors, one will naturally attain concentration.
Chapter on Inhalation and Exhalation, Chapter 185 on the Sixteen Aspects of Inhalation and Exhalation, namely, mindfulness of inhalation and exhalation being long or short;

Mindfulness of inhalation and exhalation pervading the entire body, eliminating bodily activities, experiencing joy, experiencing pleasure, experiencing mental activities, eliminating mental activities;
Mindfulness of inhalation and exhalation, experiencing the mind, causing the mind to rejoice, causing the mind to be concentrated, causing the mind to be liberated;
Mindfulness of inhalation and exhalation, following the contemplation of impermanence, following the contemplation of cessation, detachment, and cessation.
Mindfulness of inhalation and exhalation being long or short.
Question:
What is meant by long and short breath?
Answer:
It is like a person climbing a mountain, carrying a heavy load, and becoming tired, so their breath becomes short.
The practitioner is also like this, when in a coarse mind, the breath is then short.
A coarse mind refers to a restless and scattered mind.
A long breath means when the practitioner is in a subtle mind, the breath is long.
Why is this so?

Following the subtlety of the mind, the breath also follows and becomes subtle, just like this person who has become exhausted and stops, so the breath then follows and becomes subtle, at that time the breath is long.
Pervading the body means the practitioner has faith and understanding of the emptiness of the body, and then sees the wind flowing in and out of all the pores.

Excluding the body practitioner means the practitioner obtains the power of the object, and because the mind is at ease, the coarse breath then ceases. At that time, the practitioner is fully aware of the body.

Experiencing joy means this person gives rise to great joy from the mind of this meditative state. Although there was joy before, it was not able to be like this. At that time, it is called experiencing joy.
Experiencing pleasure means giving rise to pleasure from joy.
Why is this so?
If the mind obtains joy, the body becomes tranquil. If the body is tranquil, one obtains the bliss of tranquility. As it is said in the sutra:
Because the mind is joyful, the body becomes tranquil. If the body is tranquil, one experiences bliss.
The practice of observing the mind is to see the faults of joy, because it can give rise to craving.
Craving is a mental activity, because it arises from the mind.
Because craving arises from feeling, one sees feeling as a mental activity.
The practice of eliminating the mind is that the practitioner sees the faults of craving arising from feeling, and thus eliminates and extinguishes them, causing the mind to become tranquil.
He also eliminates coarse feelings, and thus it is said to eliminate the practice of the mind.
The practice of observing the mind is that the practitioner, because of eliminating the taste of feeling, sees the mind as tranquil, neither sunken nor agitated.
This mind may sometimes become sunken again, and at that time one should cause it to be joyful;
if the mind becomes agitated again, at that time one should cause it to be concentrated;
if it is free from these two states, at that time one should let it go, and thus it is said to cause the mind to be liberated.

Because the practitioner's mind is thus tranquil and still, the contemplation of impermanence arises, and through the contemplation of impermanence, all afflictions are eliminated. This is called the practice of elimination.
Because the afflictions are eliminated, the mind becomes detached. This is called the practice of detachment.
Because the mind is detached, all cessation is attained. This is called the practice of cessation.
In this way, liberation is attained in sequence. Therefore, it is called the sixteen aspects of mindfulness of inhalation and exhalation.
Question:

Why is mindfulness of inhalation and exhalation called the practice of the sages, the practice of the gods, the practice of the Brahmins, the practice of those in training, and the practice of those beyond training?
Answer:

The wind moves in the void, and the characteristic of voidness can quickly open up and destroy characteristics. The characteristic of destruction is emptiness, and emptiness is the practice of the sages, thus it is called the practice of the sages.

It is called the practice of the gods because it gives rise to the pure heavens. It is called the practice of the Brahmins because it leads to tranquility and cessation. It is called the practice of those in training because it enables one to attain the Dharma of those in training. It is called the practice of those beyond training because it is beyond training.
Question:
If one contemplates impurity and deeply detests the body, one can quickly attain liberation. What need is there to cultivate these sixteen aspects?
Answer:
The contemplation of impurity, before attaining freedom from desire, oneself detests the body, and the mind becomes confused, like taking medicine that is excessive and then becomes a disease.

In this way, impurity gives rise to deep disgust, like the bhiká¹£us on the banks of the VaggumudÄ River, due to the contemplation of impurity they deeply gave rise to disgust, drank poison, jumped off cliffs, and in various ways committed suicide.
This practice is not like that, it can attain freedom from desire without giving rise to disgust, and is therefore called superior.
Moreover, this practice is easily attained because it is based on one's own body;
impurity is easily lost.
Moreover, this practice is subtle because it can destroy one's own body;
the practice of impurity is coarse, and it is difficult to destroy the appearance of bones.
Moreover, this practice can destroy all afflictions, while impurity only destroys sexual desire.
Why is this so?
All afflictions arise from thoughts. Counting the inhalation and exhalation of breath is to cut off thoughts.
Question:
Do inhalation and exhalation belong to the body or to the mind?
Answer:
They belong to both the body and the mind.
Why is this?
They are absent in the womb, so we know they are due to the body;
If they are absent in the fourth dhyÄna and so on, and in the mindless state, we know they are due to the mind.
Question:
Inhalation and exhalation do not arise intentionally, so they should not be due to the mind.
Why is this?

This breath does not arise by intention, just as when the mind thinks of other things, the breath still comes in and goes out, just as food digests by itself and a shadow moves by itself, and it is not done by a person.
Answer:
The breath does not arise intentionally or by recollection, but only arises due to the combination of various conditions.

If there is a mind, then there is [breath], and if there is no mind, then there is not. Therefore we know it is due to the mind. There are distinctions following the mind, such as coarse mind being short and subtle mind being long.

Moreover, inhalation and exhalation are due to the stage and the mind. If one is in the stage of inhalation and exhalation, there is also a mind in the stage of inhalation and exhalation. At that time, there is the stage of inhalation and exhalation, namely the desire realm and the three meditations.
If one is in the stage of inhalation and exhalation but without a mind in the stage of inhalation and exhalation, and also without a mind, at that time there is none.
If one is in the stage without inhalation and exhalation, at that time there is also none.
Question:
When the breath arises, does it first come out or first go in?
Answer:
When born, it first comes out, and when dying, it goes in last. The same is true for coming and going in the fourth meditation.
Question:
How is this mindfulness of inhalation and exhalation called complete?
Answer:
When the practitioner attains these sixteen aspects, at that time it is called complete.
Some abhidharma masters say that it is called complete for six reasons, namely counting, following, stopping, contemplating, changing objects, and purification.
Counting means counting the exhalation and inhalation of breath from one to ten. There are three kinds of counting: equal, exceeding, and reducing.
Equal means counting ten as ten. Exceeding means counting eleven as ten. Reducing means counting nine as ten.
Following means the mind of the practitioner following the breath in and out.
Contemplating means the practitioner sees the breath attached to the body like a thread in a pearl.
Stopping means causing the mind to dwell in the exhalation and inhalation of breath.
Turning means turning the body and mind, causing the mind to experience.
The present mind and dharmas are also like this.
